bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 6, 1902

div1.p: Reed writes that the boarding house fare has improved, though the coffee is still not good. Forwood tells Reed that his chances are excellent for a permanent appointment to be the Surgeon General.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 6, 1902
div1.opener:
A chuck
under the
Chin for
Doogy--
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Friday Eve-
My darling wifie,
div1.p:
I believe
that I have attended to
all of your requests, ex-
cept in the matter of the
fish- I am going there
tomorrow morning and order
them- Have the butcher
knife and kitchen towels -
and Ping-Pong and Blossom's
photographs- I guess I
will have to hire a man
to carry my valise- I am
anxious to bring pajamas
this time & brush & comb,
if I don't forget them-
Haven't had any need
for my umbrella, since
I got back- What a dry
spell this is, although
Washington has had plenty
of rain- Am glad to re-
port that there has been
a decided improvement
in our bill of fare
up stairs- Coffee better
too, but not as good as
I could want- I was
very much amused at
Col. Forwood, who came
down, this afternoon,
to the museum to have
his picture taken- Of course,
it is intended for the news-
papers on Monday, I guess.
He told me that from
all he could gather, my
chances for the perma-
nent Surgeon Generalcy
were excellent -- where-
at I had to chuckle
heartily- He will re-
main three months, if
appointed- Told me that
much- Poor Col. Dewitt
seemed very nervous,
this afternoon, but I
think that it was be-
cause he was anxious
about Forwood's immediate
retirement- The latter seemed
very much elated over his
prospective promotion-
I am so glad that he is
going to get it, for he
heartily deserves it-
Well, goodbye Miss
House-fixer, until to-
morrow afternoon - Will
come if I can- Love to
Mrs. Stewart & Mrs. Hall-

Love & kisses for my
pretty Country lady-
